unnormalised: Chennai - The All India Tailors Association (AITA) has announced the standardization of measurement units across the country, effective 01/01/2025. This initiative aims to bring uniformity and precision to the tailoring industry, benefiting both tailors and consumers. Currently, variations in measurement practices, often reliant on regional customs and individual preferences, lead to inconsistencies in garment sizing and fit.
normalised: Chennai - The All India Tailors Association (A-I-T-A) has announced the standardization of measurement units across the country, effective first january two thousand and twenty five. This initiative aims to bring uniformity and precision to the tailoring industry, benefiting both tailors and consumers. Currently, variations in measurement practices, often reliant on regional customs and individual preferences, lead to inconsistencies in garment sizing and fit.

unnormalised: The new standards will primarily focus on transitioning tailors towards using the metric system. AITA emphasizes the use of centimeters (cm) and meters (m) for length and width measurements. Body measurements, frequently expressed in inches, will be systematically converted and documented in cm for pattern making and garment construction. A series of workshops is planned across major cities, including Mumbai, Delhi, and Kolkata, to educate tailors on the proper application of these standards, commencing Nov 2024.
normalised: The new standards will primarily focus on transitioning tailors towards using the metric system. A-I-T-A emphasizes the use of centimeter (c-m) and meter (m) for length and width measurements. Body measurements, frequently expressed in inches, will be systematically converted and documented in centimeter for pattern making and garment construction. A series of workshops is planned across major cities, including Mumbai, Delhi, and Kolkata, to educate tailors on the proper application of these standards, commencing November two thousand and twenty four.

unnormalised: “This standardization represents a significant step forward for the Indian tailoring industry,” stated Mr. Rajesh Kumar, President of AITA. "By adopting uniform measurement units, we can reduce errors, improve customer satisfaction, and facilitate smoother transactions, especially for online tailoring services. We are confident that the transition to cm and m will prove to be beneficial in the long run." The association expects a widespread adoption rate within the first year, with ongoing support and resources available to address any challenges faced by members.

unnormalised: Furthermore, AITA is collaborating with textile manufacturers and garment retailers to align sizing charts with the new standards. This collaborative effort aims to ensure a seamless experience for consumers purchasing ready-made clothing as well. The transition is expected to streamline the entire garment production process from fabric cutting to final fitting, resulting in greater efficiency and reduced material wastage. The association anticipates a growth of 15% in revenue for its members in the next financial year.
